utterances: I went through a series of rigorous medical evaluations.
One doctor demanded a nuclear stress test to prove my heart could be shocked back into life if it stopped during surgery.
A social worker questioned my motivation.
Challenged at every turn, I found myself wanting to overcome these obstacles, to be selected as the donor.
More importantly, I began empathizing with Julie.
And rather than flunking out, I passed all the tests with flying colors.
The day I received the news that I was accepted, I was genuinely elated.
Now, very soon, after our final medical exams and last-minute blood matching tests, I will play my part in this remarkable sharing of a human resource.
Since receiving that group email last winter, Julie and I have become friends.
I have found a new courage and steel, maybe for both of us.
Now, together, we wait.
(Soundbite of music)
Jeff Moyer is a writer, musician and disability advocate in Cleveland.
He's going to check in with us again, after the transplant surgery.
Ford has released the details of its cost-cutting agreement with the United Auto Workers.
And General Motors and Chrysler are expected to make their own deals before the end of the month.
Michigan Radio's Tracy Samilton has this report.
Gone forever is Ford's jobs bank that paid laid-off workers while they waited for a new job to open up at the company.
Gone too is a chunk of daily break time, Easter Monday holiday, cost of living increases, and bonuses.
Ford will also pay half of what it owes the UAW for retiree health care in stock instead of cash.
Joe Hinrichs is vice president of North American Manufacturing for Ford.
He says the changes save Ford $500 a year and bring labor costs close to those at competitors like Toyota.
We feel very, very good about the agreement that we reached but also recognize that it's fair and reasonable to our employees, given the excess that we have and given the economy that we're in.
Ford workers may have felt they had no choice.
Union leaders told the rank and file that rejecting the concessions would eventually doom Ford.
Farley Shakin(ph) studies labor issues at UC Berkley.
He says the high percentage of yes votes was not a surprise.
No one feels this recession harder than auto workers in Detroit.
Shakin says Ford gained an advantage by going first with the UAW.
Now the union will try to use the deal to limit concessions at Chrysler and General Motors, two companies worse off than Ford.
Both must cut a deal with the union by March 31st or the federal government could demand the return of its loans, triggering bankruptcy.
I think so, yes.
Moussavi is viewed a very competent economist.

Most people believe that he's a competent manager, he will put competent economists in his cabinet, and that he will pursue social change as well, according to himself and his wife - which means a lot more freedom, a lot less restrictions on the media and the press.

So those are the immediate things, the economy, which is primary concern to most Iranian voters, and many Iranian voters, particularly in the cities, feel that Ahmadinejad has botched the economy -with unprecedented levels of oil income, he still managed to drive the economy almost into ruin.
The second thing is of course international relations, which even though they don't seem to be directly linked, in Iran they are linked because the U.S.
sanctions, the unilateral sanctions, multilateral sanctions that have been posed on Iran have in fact affected the economy - which again effects the pocketbook of the average Iranian.

And of course the isolation of Iran is something that most Iranian's are uncomfortable with and would like to see more foreign investment, would like to see more business, would like to see more trade, more relations, being able to travel a little bit more freely.
All those things which Moussavi has promised he will bring to Iran.

Well, if President Ahmadinejad were to lose the election or to be forced into a runoff - which seems entirely possible, and which would be normal under the law in Iran - should we in the West interpret that as Iranian's saying we want a different approach to America?
I think so.
I think so.
I think partly.
A big part of why Ahmadinejad might lose the election is the economy at the end of the day, and that's probably the single biggest issue.

But I think beyond that, because his foreign policy, at least his rhetoric on the international stage has been so belligerent and so damaging in some people's minds to Iran, and also in terms of the sanctions that have been implied, I think that then, yes, it would also be a sign that Iranian's want a different approach to relations with the United States and with the West in general.
Hooman Majd is a writer for a number of publications, an author of ""The Ayatollah Begs to Differ."" Thanks very much.
Thank you, Steve.
(Soundbite of music)
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Melissa Block.
And I'm Robert Siegel.
President Obama was in Youngstown, Ohio today, promoting his economic policies.
It's the latest stop on his White House to Main Street tour.
NPR White House correspondent Ari Shapiro reports from the factory where President Obama delivered his pep talk.
At the heart of Youngstown's steel corridor, a mountain of wrecked cars and other scrap metal marks the entrance to V&M Star.
A hundred workers at this factory chosen by lottery stood in line in the cold and drizzle before the president arrived.
When he walked onto the stage, the response suggested that everyone in the crowd was a fan.
(Soundbite of applause)
They were not.
I don't like the bailout plan.
I think that was the stupidest thing anybody could've done.
Larry Collins is a Navy veteran who works at this plant.
He wears a stars and stripes bandana every day and he voted for John McCain in 2008.
Before the president's speech, Collins said he's very concerned about President Obama's freeze on new offshore oil drilling.
Our job here is to make oil and gas rig pipe.
That's what we do every day.
So if he's putting it on hold, how is that helping us?
So what do you want him to tell you?
Well, I'd like for him to say it's a go and let's start drilling.
The more rigs we have out there drilling, the more demand for our product.
This company is America's leading producer of pipe for oil wells.
Perhaps not the best backdrop for a presidential speech while the White House fights a massive oil spill.
But President Obama did not talk about oil today, he talked about jobs.
And a lot of people, let's just be blunt, aren't always real impressed when a governor or a president comes swooping in and talking about the economy.
Because the only headline they want to see is the headline that says: You're hired.
This factory is adding 350 jobs.
President Obama said his Economic Recovery Act is responsible.
Federal money helped extend the rail line and other infrastructure in Youngstown.
That prompted the parent company of this plant to decide to grow here.
President Obama attacked Republicans, calling them the just say no crowd.
But I think it's fair to say, any fair-minded person would say that if we hadn't acted, more people in the valley, more people in Ohio, more people across America would be out of work today.
After the speech, factory worker Larry Collins said: He did a good job, but it doesn't change my mind.
Ari Shapiro, NPR News, Youngstown, Ohio.
Now let's take a look at what voters in parts of the country were saying last night.
We'll make our way west in moment for some analysis.
But starting in the northeast, John McCain benefited mightily from the absence of one candidate, former New York mayor Rudy Giuliani.
When he pulled out of the race last week, Giuliani endorsed McCain, and that brought voters to him in droves, from New York, Connecticut and New Jersey.
Nancy Solomon reports.
State Senator Bill Baroni, who led the campaign for McCain in New Jersey, relaxed at a victory party last night with his sights now set on the general election.
Baroni says McCain was supported by veterans, moderates and independent voters.
I think John McCain is exactly the kind of Republican that can win in New Jersey, which is someone that reaches out to blue collar Reagan Democratic voters.
Exit polls found that McCain did well with voters who say security, Iraq and the economy are the issues that matter most to them.
Mark Chapin of Millburn says he had planned on voting for Giuliani and switched to McCain.
I wanted somebody who was conservative and not religious conservative, small government, open markets and low taxes.
It was very tough, because I also really liked Barack Obama.
But I thought that I might actually feel a little guilty if I didn't vote for Hillary.
Clinton won in New Jersey and New York, but Obama won in Connecticut, beating Clinton in her own back yard.
For NPR News, I'm Nancy Solomon in South Orange, New Jersey.
We now remember a politician who declared his African nation free of colonial rule, only to insist it remain under white rule.
Ian Smith was 88 when he died yesterday.
He had led Rhodesia to independence in 1965, only to face a fierce black resistance that ultimately took back the nation in 1979 and renamed it Zimbabwe.
Just three years earlier, Ian Smith had made a prediction he never quite lived down.
When he was asked if blacks would ever come to power in Rhodesia, he had this to say.
I don't believe in black majority rule ever in Rhodesia, not in a thousand years.
